Large ice fall, several lines possible from 3 to 4+. The ice is in the sun in the morning so plan accordingly.

To go down, there are 2 possibilities:

1. From the center of the waterfall, head left into the forest. 3-5m from the edge there is a big chain. (70m needed to reach the first pitch relay)

2. On the left, at the top of a small column, there is a bolted belay. (60m needed to reach the first pitch belay). Note that the bolts are not visible from the cascade.

----------------------------------------------------------------

Large cascade très épaisse. Plusieurs lignes possible allant du grade 3 à 4+. La glace est au soleil le matin donc planifier en consequence.

Pour descendre, il y a 2 possibilité:

1. Par le centre de la cascade, dirigez vous a gauche dans la forêt. 3-5m du bord il y a une grosse chaine. (70m nécéssaire pour atteindre le relais du premier pitch)

2. Par la gauche, en haut d'une petite colonne, il y a un relais bolté. (60m nécéssaire pour atteindre le relais du premier pitch). Prendre note que les bolts ne sont pas visible de la cascasde.



At km 7 on the west bank of the St-Margerite River.

------------------------------------------------------------------

Au km 7 sur la rive ouest de la rivière St-Margerite.


Ice screws

Vis à glace

This is a spectacular hard route! Steep and challenging. This should be on every hard climber's tick list. Some seasons the first pitch can be thin. The crux is higher up and several variations can be taken. The direct line up the middle offering the biggest challenge. Protection can be challenging depending on conditions.


Ice protection.

A classic wide and thick route with ice the color of coffee. Three or four pitches to the top. The first pitch is WI4/4+ depending on the year and what line the leader chooses. Belay off to one side where it angles off around 50-60 meters up to avoid the leader bombing the belayer on the next pitch. Things get steeper after this. Choose your best line up the wide flow. Belay at 60 meters or wherever is comfortable and safe. Another steep fun pitch to a flat stance at 50-60 meters. Another short pitch takes you to the trees if you are on the left side. The right side will be above the trees already. Descent: Make threads in the ice.


Sainte Margerite Headwall. This is the most obvious fat wide route in the area. Snowmobiling into the climbs offers the best way to reach the climbs versus skiing or snowshoeing the 4.5-mile approach to the cliff. Park by the dam, Barrage Sainte-Marguerite. In winter, there is usually a good snowmobile trail just to the northeast of the dam that leads out about a mile up the river.

A regular rack of screws and draws.

This incredible hard mixed line has it all - starting on verglas, heading up into a stout pillar under an overhanging free-hanger, to drytooling a crack under daggers,a big chimney and offwidth climbing, struggle out brittle jellyfish to finish up sustained steep ice.



On the wall far right of Le Mulot.

rock and ice rack.

Choose your best line up heavily cauliflowered ice to an often dry and aerated mushroomed column in a right-facing corner below a roof. Pass one bolt on the right-hand wall on your way steeply up the pillar to a bolted belay on the ledge out left. From the anchor, step back right and climb a thin narrow overhanging flow up the wall. It eases off after 100 feet or so. Climb as far as you want until you find a good safe stance above. Climb one more easier pitch to the trees. Rappel the route or traverse through spruce trees in snow over to Simon Proulx.

This is the thin pillar that starts just up and right of the wide flow of Simon-Proulx.
A couple long runners can be helpful to sling ice for protection on the crux column.

The Headwall on the Sainte Marguerite River offers some of the finest and hardest multi-pitch ice and mixed climbing in Quebec surrounded by scenic backcountry terrain.

La falaise sur la rivière Sainte Marguerite offre quelques-unes des plus belles et des plus dures parois de glace et d'escalade mixte au Québec, entourées de terrains pittoresques de l'arrière-pays.
